comments.commentBody: (2 of 3) Yet here I sit commenting online about this article, asking an online community about their thoughts instead of my friends and peers who I see daily. This represents the difficulty in criticizing these social media technologies. To a large extent, these technologies are revolutionizing society; connecting people who would have lost touch, bringing together those of similar interests, and, in certain circumstances like the Arab Spring, giving a collective voice to silenced individuals. Why are we so resistant to Facebook Graph when all it does is try to connect and guide us further? After much thought, I believe that my hostility comes from fear. I am concerned that Facebook’s new technologies are going to tap so far into my social network that I will fail to upkeep my own social network, separate from Facebook. Therefore, in response to user rugao’s statement “there is so much prejudice and trashing already. I think if this will be a positive contribution to people's life if it helps to find more relevant things”: Facebook Graph may be a positive convenience, but its threat to interpersonal relations far outweighs its technical advantages.
So my investment strategy should be to trust the gut instinct of people who consistently buy high and sell low?
It was Bernard Baruch. Joe was more ruthless than to listen to shine boys.
Ditto.  I recall back in the 90's being at Newark Airport and listening to guys in t-shirts buying and selling stocks on their cell phones.  Sheep to be shorn and shorn they were.
Reminiscent of the shoe shine kid giving Joe Kennedy a stock tip.  When mom and pop come back into the market, it is time to get out.

John,
One thing I do to alleviate the stress is to pick a number of stocks where you can sleep at night even if they go down 50% (which tehy did in 2000 and 2008). For me, that number is 30% of my wealth. If stocks tank, you keep 85% of your dough at a time when the world is devastated and everything is cheap. You will be one of the few still standing.
Not unlike all the Obama supporters who mistakenly believe the market's recent rise can be attributed to him.
Ironically, you obviously do not understand how markets work, with a lame political comment!

Whatever talking head occupies the White House is always there only for a short-term lease -- a lease paid by the taxpayer, so there is no pressure to move.  How did Bubba and Laura last so long?  Look to the permanent owners.  They ain't the taxpayers!

Ironically, if Romney had been the President sworn in this week, can you imagine how all the Republicans would be  crowing about the confidence this stock market surge shows in his new administration? Just like he predicted!   Presto,  the economy has been fixed!

Jumping in and out is exactly what you should not be doing. Sit tight the next time it goes down, put your future funds at that time in bonds and cds then move again back in when stocks goes back up again. Stop yanking your funds in and out. By doing what you are currently doing you are buying high and selling low and that my friend is a great way to go broke.
Sounds like a cheesy Schwab commercial.
Time to sell then.

NY Times headline: " Investors Regain Faith..."

Really?

More like they are desperate for some cash. Many of us who were robbed by Wall Street and/or lost jobs feel that way these days.

Faith?

No.
meant to write, 'no load, low fee' mutual funds (and don't pay an 'advisor' that 1% typically charged ). Do it yourself, but educate yourself first.

News flash - Rampant currency debasement and 14 TRILLION in debt to bail out malinvestments. And the Fed is injecting 85 BILLION a month in buying toxic waste. It's the greatest Ponzi scheme in the history of the planet.

Every time they start hyping the stock market it generally means that those who own great quantities of stock at over inflated prices are looking to cash out. Remember this, because it is generally true: SMALL FISH DO NOT EAT BIG FISH.

When the market bubble collapses, all of the excess liquidity the government has been pumping into the market is going to be mopped up, and not by you. If the stock market did not periodically collapse, as it is intended to do, then we would all be a miserable bunch of millionaires. Miserable because, in that instance, a can of tuna would cost you about $12.00. The stock market is over inflated. Any fool can see that. Only, people who are "invested" in the market, through their pension plans or what have you, want to believe that happy days are here again. They have no one to blame but themselves for believing the deception.

Especially when some of the forces working against us are employing graduates of MIT where they are taught things like how to shed risk via CDOs or derivatives (invented by an MIT graduate). I mean, c'mon, when you're top schools are teaching kids how to rob us blind, how are you going to fair?
As the article stated, the market is up 120% since 2009! That's a lot of money if you didn't pull the rip cord!
If you  believe this, there are easy ways to make big bets on a market decline.  What percentage of your assets have you staked on this "sure-fire assumption"?   Just curious.
Whenever headlines proclaim the small investor is back, you can bet that Wall Street is getting ready to sell, WHICH way is the exit:}
Anyone who uses a broker is too dumb to invest.  He's ripping you off.  He wins whether the mkt goes up or down.
Huh? A new Eastern philosophy? Not very much in tune with the folks the last 200 years around these quarters...

A box of mac and cheese from the babysitter is bad parenting? I guess KJ should have forgone her evening out, or her business meeting, or whatever required her to be away from her home, to make the kids individual cheese souffles.

You wisely say "what is safe in one city or town, or region of the country, is not necessarily so in another." Then you arbitrarily declare that DG is being neglectful, when you know absolutely nothing of the particular area -- in a city that covers 300 square miles -- in which DG lives Assumptions, much?

Why do you say having the babysitter "cook" a box of mac and cheese is bad parenting? What would have been good parenting? Cooking the mac and cheese so the babysitter didn't have to (and could text/facebook/tweet instead)? Or is is the mac and cheese that you find objectionable? She should have had the babysitter prepare a healthier meal? Or prepared one herself? Maybe you don't like that mom wasn't home for dinner?

OK, the mac and cheese comment was a bit much (I used to just leave the babysitter money for pizza), but I absolutely do agree with you about dogs.

http://fewbricksshy.blogspot.com/

Why is the writer having her babysitter prepared boxed mac and cheese for her kid(s)? That seems the antithesis of helicopter parenting, teetering into bad parenting.

I am as annoyed as anyone by hovering, neurotic parents, but it must be said that the US is not what it was when I was a child allowed to roam free by age 8 (in a large city), and walk to friends' neighborhood houses by age 6. What was acceptable -- and safe -- in the 1960s is irresponsible and potentially dangerous in 2013. What is safe in one city or town, or region of the country, is not necessarily so in another. What DG of NYC (post below) is doing with her 9-year-old is neglectful, by my measurement. It's also unkind. I was a "latchkey" kid from the age of 11, and I hated coming home to an empty house. I remember a man stopping his car beside me when I was walking home from school, and trying to lure me in. And then I arrived home to no one. By the time I was 13 I was happy to not have Mom off at work, but a 9-year-old is still very much a child who needs protection and security. Too young to be home alone.

My mother told me it was time to do my own wash as soon as I was tall enough to reach the washing machine. Ditto cooking, although we rotated that chore around he family. Responsibility is good for children, as long as it is age appropriate. Don't tell the 7-year-old to take care of the dog as some sort of life lesson.. The dog will suffer.
She comes from a family that produced Churchill and the Duke of Malborough one of Britain's greatest military leaders.

I live in New York City and I feel like it is the safest city in the USA, the best city I can imagine raising my kids in, thanks to the recent gun control legislation. And I sincerely hope that what you say is true, that it will lead to more legislation in the form of handgun bans. That would be great.

Unfortunately, BeadyEye, he does have everything to do with you and your guns in this case. All of these "morons" were assembling to make a point about your supposed right to bear arms, and representing you. Those who shot themselves made a very clear point about the statistics of gun ownership.
Sarah Palin.
At least he went and fought not like too many of our Neo-Cons who talk the talk but when it was their time to fight,failed to walk the walk.
What's the sentiment where you live? Are people aware and angry? Organizing?

3 of McCains sons were in the military. 2 in the navy, one in the Marines.

The officer corps mainly comes from the middle classes, particularly in families of military tradition.

Enlisted is a mix of lower class, middle class, and those trying to clean up their lives.

Very few 'rich' ever serve in the military...but to be fair was that ever not the case??? (besides WWII)
